instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - stuck at 5v after plugged into external display
threads.message:
This one had no liquid damage, but was plugged in and powered by an external monitor before it fried. I replaced one of the CD32 chips as nothing was coming up on amp meter on that one port. then i got the 5V back on that port. Just in case replaced both of them in case one was causing the no 20V

scanned the board and saw that <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> was fried, replaced that
then i did some more checking and realised f6700 was blown too so replaced that as well. still no difference 

I then saw that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> was only 10ohms from to ground. I injected 3V and saw that <CHIP>U8210</CHIP> was lit up on thermal. removed that but still had 500ma short on that line. I then saw that there's a small amount of heat coming from under WIFI chip 

this board is a nightmare...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - stuck at 5v after plugged into external display
threads.message:
Seems that board is trash.
Let it more time under voltage injection and confirm if wifi chip is the culprit.
Also disconnect J6700.
